definitions.usage_note: 可数名词（指具体特权）或不可数名词（指特权概念）。可指法律/社会特权，也可指一种荣幸感。

sentences.en: Education should be a right, not a privilege.
sentences.zh: 教育应是权利，而非特权。

sentences.en: It was a privilege to meet such a distinguished scholar.
sentences.zh: 能见到这样一位杰出学者是一种荣幸。

sentences.en: Wealth often brings certain privileges in society.
sentences.zh: 财富往往带来社会上的某些特权。

sentences.en: It's a privilege to work with such a talented team.
sentences.zh: 与如此才华横溢的团队共事是一种荣幸。

collocations.explain: 表示特权的所属或内容

sentences.en: He enjoyed the privilege of diplomatic immunity.

prerogative.diffs: prerogative 侧重因职位或身份而固有的权利；privilege 更泛指特殊待遇

sentences.en: It is the prerogative of the president to appoint ambassadors.
sentences.zh: 任命大使是总统的特权。

disadvantage.diffs: 与 privilege 带来的优势相对

definitions.translation: 给予特权；使享有特殊待遇
definitions.usage_note: 及物动词。较正式，多用于被动语态。

sentences.en: Diplomats are privileged with immunity from local prosecution.
sentences.zh: 外交官享有不受当地起诉的特权。

sentences.en: We are privileged to have her as our guest speaker.
sentences.zh: 能有她作为我们的特邀演讲嘉宾是我们的荣幸。

sentences.en: Members are privileged to use the exclusive lounge.
sentences.zh: 会员享有使用专属休息室的特权。

collocations.explain: 常见于 be privileged to 结构

sentences.en: I was privileged to attend the ceremony.

etymology.origin: 来自拉丁语 privilegium，由 privus（私人的）+ lex/legis（法律）构成，原意为“针对或有利于个人的法律”。
etymology.history: 古罗马时指赋予个人或群体的特殊法律权利，后引申为“特权、特殊待遇”。

privileged.translation: 有特权的；荣幸的；得天独厚的
privileged.rule: privilege 的形容词/过去分词形式

privacy.rule: 与 privilege 同根（priv- 私人），均强调“私”的概念

sentences.en: Everyone has the right to privacy.

common_mistakes.wrong: have the privilege to do sth
common_mistakes.correct: have the privilege of doing sth
common_mistakes.explain: 表示“有幸做某事”时，privilege 后用 of + -ing，不用 to do；但 be privileged to do 是正确的。

mnemonics.content: priv-（私人）+ lege（法律）→ 针对私人的特别法律 → 特权。可与 private、privacy 联想记忆。
